title: Hong Kong activists call on Merkel for support
text:
Protesters face off with police outside the Legislative Council Building on September 2, 2019 in Hong Kong | Chris McGrath/Getty Images Hong Kong activists call on Merkel for support The German chancellor will fly to China this week for talks.

BERLIN — Activists pushing for democracy in Hong Kong have appealed to German Chancellor Angela Merkel for support ahead of her upcoming trip to China.

In an open letter published by German tabloid Bild, a group of activists, including pro-democracy leader Joshua Wong, called on Merkel and her team to "express concern" over the situation in Hong Kong and to "convey our demands to the Chinese government" during the chancellor's trip, which kicks off late on Thursday.

Their demands include the withdrawal of the contentious extradition bill that prompted months of mass protests across the territory, though that request now appears to have been satisfied as Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam said on Wednesday that she would pull the bill.

The activists also call for the unconditional release of arrested protestors and an independent investigation into the conduct of the police and government officials during the protests.

Merkel is leading a delegation of business leaders on a visit to China for talks, which will include breakfast with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang. She will also be hosted by President Xi Jinping for dinner and meet with students as part of the trip.

In their letter, the activists wrote: "Germany should also be on its guard doing business with China, as China does not respect international law and has repeatedly broken its promises."

Wong and the other co-signatories leaned on Merkel's personal experience growing up in the former East Germany. "Chancellor Merkel, you grew up in the GDR. You have first-hand experience of the terror of a dictatorial government," the letter said.

Merkel discussed the situation in Hong Kong with U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson during his visit to Berlin late last month; the German capital has become a destination for pro-democracy dissidents fleeing both Hong Kong and mainland China over recent years.

The U.S. Embassy in Berlin tweeted that it agrees with the contents of the letter.
description: The German chancellor will fly to China this week for talks.
